description:
It is just as we remembered! Good is still delicious! We used to come in for breakfast every weekend with my husband and son. It was our weekend family breakfast spot. 
It was our time to get out, give me a break from cooking and spending quality time discussing what we did during the week and just enjoying each other's company type of place. We would always sit in the back in the corner for a more intimate feel.
I would always order the menudo or chilaquiles and they would order either chorizo con huevos or chilaquiles. 
This time my son and I visited and I ordered the menudo and my son ordered chorizo con huevos. I had my coffee and my son had horchata. They gave us a basket of chips and some salsa. The salsa was perfect and spicy! My fave!
We enjoyed our food very much and reminisced. We had a great time and service was awesome! You are able to watch the cook make the food. If you want authentic Mexican food then this is the place to go! 
Enjoy!
author: Jennifer C.

description: Love Mexican food and this place always hits the spot with no matter how simple or how complicated your food order is.
author: Jess D.

description: The best authentic mexican food! Blaaaaaaat!my go to when i got a hang over or jus feelin la vida loca‍
author: Ron S.

description: I don't understand how this restaurant is a 4 star on yelp.  I had the menudo and huevos rancheros.  The food had terrible taste.
author: Salvador S.

description:
I've stopped in here a few times for a veggie burrito to-go and it's very good; everything tastes fresh.  
Nice, warm, comfort food and very nice employees. 
Also, no line.
author: Lame Lake Meese Z.

description: Best caldo de res I've ever had! Yum this was my first time here. Just chose it randomly while in my visit to San Francisco. Will definitely return.
author: Elena S.

description: Legit Mexican food. I asked for a non spicy salsa, they gave me a warm one that could have been my meal, alone. Enchiladas were on point, all well.
author: Antonio G.

description:
Ate here last week, and will most likely never come here again.  Ordered breakfast specials and orchata drinks.  We were all sipping our drinks, when my daughter started to freak out, and pretty much got me frazzled as I couldn't understand what was going on until we looked on the wall next to our seating and there were cockroaches.  We called over the waitress to let her know to cancel our food orders and that we would be leaving.  She just laughed at us about the cockroach situation.  Like WTF!!!!  Are you kidding me.  Do you honestly think I would sit at this table while large cockroaches with baby sacs night encroach upon my food, purse, or body.  Oh hell no!  

Food may be good, but I'm not eating in a cockroach infested establishment!!!
author: Karen B.

description: We ate at this restaurant after the Carnaval Parade. I had the steak burrito and my wife had a fish burrito. My steak burrito was a very generous size and was authentic. My wife's burrito was also the same generous size and she couldn't finish hers so I also ate part of hers since I have a huge appetite . The fish burrito is a go for me the next time I eat here.
author: Michael L.

description: I eat in this place once or twice a month, and I do not intend to return anymore, from the moment the waitress served me the food she did not bring me the tortillas after 20 minutes, but if she talking with other employees, the place almost empty I think it's not fair for the client that this kind of thing happens, thinking twice before coming to this restaurant
author: Sergio S.

description: I had the birria here and it was great. Besides great food, I like this place because it is very authentic and very friendly.
author: Mete R.

description: This is my go to place for ceviche, tacos and arroz con frijoles. The staff is outstandingly sweet and takes care of you no matter what you ask and how much you ask it. They always have music on and even local musicians come to play during the day. Very family oriented and the food is amazing which makes me want more. They have free chips and salsa and again the food there is out of the world
author: Shalom M.

description: Great food, great service . The food was served fast and accurate. Definitely will come back if I am in town again.
author: Malinda R.

description:
Lucked out on this place, because BART was down for hours.  Stopped here to avoid the rain storm for a bit.

Beef tongue (I want more!)
Grilled chicken quesadilla 
Kids plate - rice, beans, carne asada (delicious steak) 
Best flan ever!!!
Jello (for my son)
author: Denise M.

description:
This restaurant was exactly what my Midwestern living/California born heart wanted. I got the cheese enchilada plate, which came with 2 enchiladas, rice, and beans. Perfectly cheesy, and saucy! I enjoyed the freshly grated cheese which added such a great punch of flavor.

The chips, salsa, and pico came on interesting little plates but they were quick to refill as necessary. The chips were more of the healthy variety, which were good, though I was craving the more fried tasting variety.

Bring your cash!
author: Hannah R.

description: Came to Chavas for a date night tonight and i'm so so so happy with that choice. we had the caldo de res and the birria al horno. no regrets! both plates were full of flavor and well served. the caldo was comforting and so good. both plates came with rice and tortillas hechas a mano! the aguas were also super good--we had the jamaica and frutas mixtas. to make things even better, the customer service was super friendly. 10/10 would recommend. if you miss your mommas mexican cooking i recommend giving this place a shot! :)
author: Arianna A.

description:
After such a good experience at Gallardos, I wanted to return there but had to make it through my list of birria places in SF.. so we ventured to the next one on our list.  It was further into the Mission district near Bernal Heights.  This time no line up... i did expect that since reviews mentioned it's not very busy... but busy enough we were seated right away. Ordered our birria and huevos con chorizo since we were having chorizo cravings.  The huevos con chorizo was a joke, never again. Bad chorizo with scrambled eggs... now onto the main Birria. This time there was no choice to have the meat separated from the broth so we ordered it as a soup. It was a big bowl and the broth was much better than Gallardos. However it stops there the meat was rather chewy and gamey... not my favourite, I was so disappointed and will not be returning here.. Off the list.

Value 2.5/5 pricey for what you get
Atmosphere 3/5
Service 4/5 fast service
Quality 3/5
overall 12.5/20
author: Nina S.

description:
The actual prices are nearly 50% over the ones listed here.

The pozole is way too salty.
author: Manny F.

description:
It was okay.

The food was okay - the lengua needs more seasoning. I did request some tomatoes and cilantro which made it yummier.

The service is friendly but they did seem to forget Bretts tortillas. 

Not wowed about this spot.

Do like the open atmosphere -- not sure if I will go back.
I rarely say this but it was "meh" not bad but meh. Sorry guys!!!
author: Alissa H.

description:
what i ordered... super burrito with carnitas

super burrito was good... lots of rightly cooked carnitas and full of delicious guac.

ambiance... good (traditional with fine murals)
service... good (nice and very apologetic because it took them awhile to churn out my food but it was expected for the event that just finished nearby)
cost... $ (fair)
author: Gors P.

description: Came by for some dinner and they have some killer comida!!  They have a variety of dishes, which is rad and the wait staff is real friendly too. Try their mole enchiladas-I promise, you will not be disappointed!
author: Ricardo S.

description: Everything was delicious, had the queso fundido and chorizo egg bean and cheese burrito and it was on point. The salsa was really good also. And the handmade tortillas were amazing.
author: Anthony M.

description:
Some of the best authentic, reasonably priced Mexican food left in the mission. It's a local kind of place with a wide range of options. Tacos are not their speciality here, but their burritos and other home cooked-style foods are very good.

Service is friendly.
author: Thea S.

description: Great food. Brought the family here and ordered a variety of stuff. The Birria and Menudo were fantastic. The burritos were sooo good!  Not quite a 5star burrito like La Taqueria up the street, but a close 41/2 star. I also tried a Sope and it was great. The carne asada from this place is one of the best I've had, which made the burritos, tacos, and so good. I'm giving this place 4 stars because it's a CASH ONLY restaurant. This age, I can't believe restaurants can't make it convenient for customers to use credit or debit.
author: G. I.

description: Service can go a long way. Some restaurants have great food, but lack service. Today my server was a lil boy named Chris. No taller than 3'8''. He asked how I was doing, what can I get you, cleaned my table. The cutest toddler. If I knew his schedule I would come around then. His apron was pocket size. He took in some tips too.
author: Steven C.

description:
OK - so if you are a tourist, don't go here.

I have passed this place approximately 1000 times on my way home and never noticed it.

I went in on a weekday for lunch and was one of only two people there - in this huge outdated space. Then I saw a sign for cash only. My expectations were low.

I ordered a super burrito, but made all kinds of changes - no rice, no pico, no tortilla, mole chicken cut up in pieces.  They accommodated me. Didn't up charge me. The portion was huge.

For $8.65, I had a licking the plate good meal.

If they added this to the menu, I'd go a often. Was yum.
author: Andrew K.

description: We waited a long time for our food. My daughters plate came first a few minutes later my plate came to the table and my husbands came 10 minutes later. Food wasn't what we thought it was or showed in yelp reviews. Expensive especially for not having quality food
author: Sonnet U.

description:
I've been coming here for so many years, I honestly can't remember how many !   I guess I should finally tell how good this place is. I have eaten at MANY taquerias and Mexican restaurants throughout SF, most upon recommendations of other friends and co-workers, but this is the only place I recommend for Mexican food in the Mission district. Years ago this place would be crowded for lunch, and as another reviewer noted, the lunch crowds of late number well under a dozen diners at any one moment. I recall this downturn after that last economy crash, and perhaps it was unrelated (other restaurants opening up nearby?), but the quality and service is as great as ever. I forever have had the lluevos rancheros, and without disappointment, but because they finally added burritos (which they originally did not have - not inexcusable as burritos, as we know, are an American invention!), and now I am hooked on the vegetarian burrito. I get it "mojado" (red source on outside, with some cheese and other goodness added) and for just $8 I can eat my fill!  Chips and a little salsa (less amount than in years past, though . . . ) on the side for free. Good selection of drinks, refrescas and such to help the meal go well. The ambiance is great, and reminds me of many places I've eaten in Mexico itself. Nice wall paintings (large!) also make this place a little unique from other places. They still make tortillas by hand (they used to crank them out for the crowds so had an almost full-time lady working that station), and service staff are delightful, accommodating and friendly as can be, even to any first-timers. So do yourself a favor and give it a shot . . . I think you'll enjoy it as much as I do !!
(It is cash only, though, but they have an ATM nearby if you don't notice that announcement)
author: Mark K.

description: Absolutely DELICIOUS mexican food, great service, fresh-tasting food, homemade vibe. We loved this place! The tortillas and queso fundido are insanely good, and the house salsas (red and green) are amazing. We each ordered a different kind of meat (carnitas, carne asada, shrimp, chorizo) and all of them were equally tasty. Go for the wet burrito for maximum tastiness!!!
author: May B.

description:
Been here so many times I can't number them. Heard they had lease issues; landlord smells money. But it seems that it may have been resolved. I am glad, cause I love this place.

Seven days a week, they crank out really good food!

Fresh, delicious, house made tortillas, birria, pozole, and chilies. Machaca con Huevos, excellent Coctail Camarons and flautas. This is sit down, eat in, knife and fork, Mexican home style cooking.

You want a foil wrapped super burrito, they can do it, but I recommend you go stand line at El Farrolito. This isn't hipster chow. Mostly latino families and older folks that don't need to eat at the new-new place their smart phones told them to.

Good food, good price, good people. They'll never make it in this neighborhood. Oh, right, they've been in business for two decades. Almost forgot...
author: Statin Island V.

description: I left a review here & somehow it got deleted. Hmm. Isn't that funny. This place served me salsa with dead bugs in it. This place needs to be inspected ASAP. this is disgusting!!!
author: Lauren W.

description: Beer is ice cold, salsa is fcuking hot, lol. Tortilla chips were stale, great staff, my breaded shrimp could have been cooked a little longer, it had the same texture as fried calamari, cool that they play music, beans abs rice were fairly plain
author: Elle G.

description:
I'm afraid Jamie W. and I are creatures of habit when it comes to eating cheap Mexican in the Mission. With the endless choices, we always seem to come down to the same four places - El Farolito, La Corneta, Taqueria Cancun and El Zocalo. That's why it was a bit of a stretch for us psychologically to consider going to Chava's on the next block from El Farolito. We came here early Sunday afternoon, and it was quite packed with families feasting after going to church services.

We were about to leave until the zaftig hostess cleared a side table just for us. Chips and salsa immediately came to our table (see photo), and we could tell they were freshly made in the kitchen. Always a good sign. There was a lot on the menu, although it looked from the other tables that the most popular menu items were big bowls of soup. But as usual, we didn't follow the norm. Jamie went into his comfort zone and ordered the $7 Super Nachos with Beef, which were fine but really didn't stand out on their own (see photo).

I decided to take advantage of the weekend-only availability of goat. Yes, goat... so I ordered the $10.75 Birria al Horno con Arroz y Frijoles (Goat with Rice and Beans). Accompanied by their steaming hot, housemade flour tortillas, the goat was quite savory with a consistency similar to pot roast. Before I finished my second self-service soft goat taco, the waitress delighted me with a huge bowl of Birria (see photo). What a treat. I immediately put all the remaining goat and rice in the hearty broth. Really delicious. The soup is definitely worth a return visit.

FOOD - 4 stars...the birria is definitely the standout here - and get the goat if you're here on the weekend
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...looks like pretty much like every other formica-dominated Mexican Mission eatery
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...bonus points for giving me the complimentary soup
TOTAL - 4 stars...best to eat here on a brisk day, livestock optional
author: Ed U.

description: The burrito was the size of a newborn and the carnitas was so fatty and all rendered at the bottom of the tortilla and it was great. The chips were yellow corn which isn't my fave but it was still good. Salsa was fresh and service was fast. My boyfriends mimosa was the size of his face and the OJ was fresh squeezed.
author: Maureen L.

description: The main thing I remember about this place is that is was EMPTY, only us and a street person talking though her imaginary bluetooth with no phone or device present.  The reason this is somewhat significant is because all the other places up and down the street were packed with waiting lines and people squeezing into the hipster "patios" (cattle pens?).  The food was unremarkable, the service slow, and rather confused. But the portions were very large and we did get what we ordered, and the salsa was VERY good.
author: LeAnne L.

description: I love this place because they make their own tortillas, and have a dedicated person who just presses and makes the tortillas to order.  The fresh tortillas make all the difference in their tacos and dinner plates.  Great food and great value!
author: Carla D.

description:
I had a Carnitas burrito and a horchatta. The burrito wasn't huge or even "regularly' sized. It would almost say that it was a little small. But when I was done, I didn't feel hungry. The carnitas was OK, maybe just ever so slightly dry. The fresh avocado was great, and a nice touch. 

Must've gotten really lucky, as I found parking right out front, and walked in and had maybe a 3 minute wait. I was told that the line can get pretty crazy here.
author: Benny N.

description:
I come from Texas - San Antonio to be exact - where Tex-Mex is pretty much a staple. So of course, it's not too long after I move to San Francisco that my craving for Tex-Mex starts kicking in and I find myself literally spending hours searching for a good place. Disclaimer: I've been told that there's a pretty big difference between real Mexican and Tex-Mex cuisine so I'm going to specify that I'm writing about Tex-Mex.

I searched high and low for a place that serves fajitas and finally found Chava's. Here are my thoughts about my experience in order of occurrence.

It's located in a semi sketchy part of Mission. Don't think I'm going to get hurt or anything, but definitely not the cleanest. That's Mission district for ya I guess.

Cash only sign - good thing I had some paper on me. Usually not a super big fan of places that only take cash. Come on, it's 2015, time to upgrade.

HOLY MOLY FREE GUACAMOLE! Normally, places charge $1 for guac, but it came with the complementary chips and salsa. Easily earned some major points for this place. Salsa was pretty good too!

The fajitas didn't come on a sizzling plate like I'm used to in Texas, but they were pretty good none the less. I ordered charro beans instead of refried - mistake. The charro beans were incredibly bland, sticking with the fried fat next time.

Overall, I'm a fan. They don't make em like they do in Texas, but it'll satisfy my Tex-Mex craving well enough.
author: Betty W.

description: Sitting here for counting 17 minutes for a check to leave because I would rather go somewhere else than eat here. I had the birria & my dad had the chilaquiles. Food from the kitchen was plain. The oregano they had in a shaker was really old, lots of stems, and was too too perfumy. Chilaquiles had no tang on the salsa and by the time the plate got to the table the sour cream made everything look like  a little throw up. Quick on customer service, and on delivering what you ask for. I would say save your money because there are better places to get plain food on Mission Street. However, the orange juice they squeeze in the kitchen is delicious.
author: David C.

description: I've been here quite a bit and was there yesterday morning for breakfast. I'd have to say that the chilaquiles was not as good as it used to be. The salsa and chips are still my favorite here. Their stews and soups are good but they only take cash and the service is a bit slow.
author: Marlene T.

description: I have been here twice. Great customer service. The food is alright. What's even great is that they open early and close late.
author: C G.

description: Food was good and enjoyable but I hate when running into businesses in major cities that don't accept cards. I don't like carrying cash and if a business doesn't have signage regarding not accepting cards it is annoying to find that out after ordering.
author: Patrick P.

description: Loud as f#ck in here. TV blaring, florescent lights that buzz and mariachis weaving their way throughout. The staff are informal but helpful and the food is great. A sit-down family Mexican restaurant is a rarity and this place is one of the best. Nothing too adventurous so the gringos can experiment and the brownsters get the comfort food they're looking for. Go here! With earplugs.
author: Mario T.

description:
Yuckala, fuchi, ewh, ugh, gag reflux sound, barf. People rating this place as 4 stars have gone loco and have killed every taste bud on their tongue. This place was disgusting.  Wet burrito was smothered in below average sause, watery gac, sour cream and shredded chicken that included cartilage, (this was the same chicken given to us on two tacos, yes, cartilage included there too). At the request of an 8 yr old we ordered french fries. They were frozen and presented  on a dish with burt black flakes, complementary effect of using and reusing frying oil over and over. The veggie burrito was soggy. The watery gac, sour cream and water from the bean juice, created a special kind of wet burrito. Picture holding your burrito, slightly tilting your head and taking a big bite on the right side- now sip it all in before your burrito smoothie runs down your hand! 
Also, this place has no signage to let you know it's cash only. Total bust!
author: Nico S.

description:
Food that will make you nostalgic for a home you may have never had. 

Chavas is set up like many of the taquerias on Mission and in the surrounding area. An open air kitchen, decent amount of seating, and some music playing in the background. Unlike many of the the other taquerias, Chavas put in the extra effort when it comes to decor, cleanliness, and an overall atmosphere that's more inviting. Well
worth it for a premium of .75 cents to $1 in comparison to their competitors.

For lunch I ordered the retailer chicken burrito. Side wise it was almost exactly the same as the other restaurants, but the flavor had much more depth than the other chicken burritos I tried. Their chicken is stewed in a red sauce for hours until it has taken in all of the spices in the pot, no matter how subtle. It's then mixed with a very soft white rice and refried beans, then rolled tightly into a burrito. Served alongside a handful of chips and a semi-spicy green jalapeño salsa. It's the kind of meal that can only be perfectly complimented by a Mexican sangria soda or an imported glass bottle of Coke.

While not a connoisseur, I was able to try a few Mission taquerias and this was hands down the best overall experience.
author: Armand K.

description:
This meal was honestly only okay for me. My friend who hails from Honduras swears it's the best. I respectfully disagree with her, although I must confess that I've not tasted tortillas any fresher or more delicious than here, save Mexico itself. 

Wonderfully fluffy and slapped-happy-to-perfection, they were... at least 1-2 mm thicker than anywhere else you'd order, I would wager! =)

One order of mole con pollo, and one order of enchiladas con mole..a cafe, and a jugo de zanahoria, and we ended up waddling outa there, and myself sporting one of those infamous doggy bags.

Flavor of the mole fell really flat for me. First, it took a LOONG time to be served. Secondly, the mole was only lukewarm when it reached me, which was a bit annoying. Thirdly, I've had much richer, deeper tasting mole whose flavor really goes deep. Not so for this place. Oh well...

I'm sorta with Jason B... 2.5 would be more accurate rating, but I was bowled over by the tortillas... bien hecho, Chavas! The humungous glass of juice was also very fresh and I looked carefully in the mirror in days following for any signs of orange undertones.. Phew!

In the heart of the Mission, just a few doors up from Diandas, same side of the street.

PS Think i snagged photo of the Cortina Romantica singer as well
author: Jana C.

description:
I stumbled upon this place by accident when the Quickly next door was closed. So happy I did! I had a carnitas taco to go and it was def in the top three best that I've ever had. That says a lot because I grew up eating Mexican food.

Only thing is, I wish they accepted credit cards. Its CASH only.
author: Jeanette S.

description:
No idea how this place has 4 stars, might be the worst Mexican food I've had in SF. My family and I came here over memorial day weekend because La Taquria was closed and was provided with both mediocre food and service. Nobody was satisfied with the food. The chips were straight out of a bag, the guacamole was terribly presented and lacked flavor. Everything just looked sloppy...which you can somtimes get away with at Mexican joints, if the flavor is there. 

Only good thing about this place were the home made beverages hot/cold.
author: Michael P.

description: I was craving chilaquiles and they hit the mark! Excellent! Not greasy and full of flavor!   They have the best mimosas! Freshly squeezed Oj served in a huge margarita glass! Service was great as well, very nice and welcoming. Look foward to going back!
author: Ladyreyes R.

description: Delicious food, decent portions, but until the end of the meal we had no idea it was cash only; then having to use an inside ATM that had its own withdrawal fee. Make sure you have cash if you come by.
author: Kuhray V.

description: Salsa really spicy and the choriqueso was excellent. The food was pretty good and the people were friendly but probably can use a little help.
author: Alex C.

description: I've been eating at this place my whole life and it saddens me that I'm only going to get them 1 but I found a bug in my salsa! And it dead so you know it had been in there for a while! And the lady scooped it into the bowl so she could have spotted it but no. So sorry to say that my family and I will never eat here again.
author: Dana T.

description:
Here I am, sitting in my office out in snowy Western Massachusetts, pining for Chavas' Chiliquiles. If you haven't been here & had that- do it now. Do it for me.

 I lived on Potrero Hill for over a decade back before the Mission was prime real estate & first started going to this place when it was a hole in the wall over on,uh, 19? There was a fire. Thank god they resurrected on the Mission. 

They are  the Chiliquies of my dreams. A plate of these with cold beer will easily fix the hangovers of two deeply damaged people. Strong armed ladies behind the counter make their own tortillas BY HAND, for the love of god. And although I know, it's called "Migas" in Texas, these chiliquiles feature eggs/a HUGE side of carbs/ lots of cheez & crema swimming in a perfect greasy sauce. Amazing.

 I'm making myself home sick.... sigh.  Maybe they don't make their tortillas by hand anymore? Maybe they changed the sauce? Maybe it's as different as the Mission is these days. I don't know- but I will make a pilgrimage here next time I visit the bay. 

Won't you please go find out? I'm sure you won't be sorry.

( I wonder if they put out calendars? If this review moves you to try this place, would you please send me one? thanks )
author: Judith M.

description: I was a little under the weather and wanted hot soup. Chava's was the right choice! Flavorful, fresh, and huge. The home made tortillias, chips, and salas were far above average, too.
author: Ben G.

description: Best chicken soup *anywhere* - always cures my colds. Great service, authentic food, abundant portions.
author: SF R.

description: This restaurant has been in the city for 40 years at various previous locations.  We love their weekend brunch for Machaca and other eggs dishes, menudo, and chicken, birria and meatball soups as well as the old Mexican standbys. Their murals are worth taking a peak even if your don't want to eat there that day.  And there is nothing like homemade tortillas freshly made since you've sat down.   Support the local families who've supported and made this city what it is!
author: Debbie L.

description:
Every time my wife and I want a real authentic Mexican flavor just as in the old markets in Mexico, we go to Chava's , it is the real deal , forget about La Taqueria or Chevy's or worse Chipotle!  that's not mexican they are  more like gringo/texmex/ mexican .
Chavas is awesome so many dishes, so big and good portions, and the ladies there are very kind and nice people, great to eat there, very often. I totally recommend Birria al Horno and Consome ( gout soup ) great for hangovers !
author: Jaime J.

description:
Monday my heart was in El Paso. I so badly wanted to be there so much that I spent the morning feeling sad and felt like crying.

I'm just going to say it. With sincere apologies to San Diego, Chicago and LA El Paso is home to the very best Mexican food in the United States of America. Certainly it's proximity to Juarez is a huge help (which by the way, is worth checking out for yet another culinary adventure).

But I can't be in two (in this case 3) places at once. But with El Paso on my mind and up early on NYE I craved Mexican. The Mission is not El Paso, but in my most humble of opinions, it's very close and there are some dishes that you can find here that are almost equally as good. One example of this are the chilaquiles at Chava's. 

This dish is the most comforting breakfast food you can find in the entire neighborhood. Soft warm corn tortillas made by the hands of angels, tossed and pan fried with a deep rojo (or verde) sauce with eggs and your choice of meat, pork or chicken (veggies too!). This dish will wipe out that you hunger for quality Mexican food that you so covet. Chilaquiles will warm your soul and will make you feel like you have found yourself in a small friendly village in central Mexico surrounded by some of the friendliest people who open their hearts and treat you like family.

For those of us living in the 'burbs, it's worth the drive. And given that Monday is a semi-holiday, the drive was a breeze and finding parking at 8:00 could not have been easier. The service was so fast that I was back home in plenty of time to catch the opening kickoff (which again was only another heartbreaker). 

Happy New Year.
author: V B.

description:
Delicious home style cooking yummy salsa guacamole and corn tortillas 
I ate the carnitas  - very tasty my friend had the chicken mole also very good  for dessert arroz con leche aka rice pudding - delicious very nice staff will go here again
author: lyn m.

description:
Right in the heart of the mission, this place stands out as a good Mexican comfort food place.  For all the years eating here the only thing that has changed are the prices -- its still a bargain for the portions but the price has creeped north.

Weekends are all about their caldos -- great on a cold day or to recover from a long night of drinking.  The chicken soup is good, could use more veggies, broth is tasty and add a little chile to spice it up and you are set.

My go to dish is the chile colorado, nice cubes of beef simmered in red chili served with rice and beans and enjoyed with thick hand made cord tortillas.

So go and eat up.
author: G R.

description:
Note: This review is based solely upon my most recent visit for breakfast (and that specific meal) on Saturday morning. I have eaten there many times before and if I had gotten their Chilaquiles, this would be a 4-Star review. I feel that their Chilaquiles are one of the best I have ever had, but I am partial to their version as those were the first Chilaquiles that I ever had (twenty-plus years ago now).

As it was, I got the Huevos a la Mexicana ~ 3 huevos revueltos con cebolla, tomate y chile verde (3 scrambled eggs with onions, tomato, and green bell pepper); se sirves con arroz, frijoles (refritos) y tortillas (de maíz) hechas a mano (served with rice, refried beans, and handmade corn tortillas). Now this was a very good breakfast and I would order it again there... if they didn't have the Chilaquiles on the menu. That is really worth going back, and back, and back for.

Plus, their fresh, home-made corn tortillas are always great with any breakfast.

If you would like to read a more detailed take on my desayuno mexicano (and other foolishness), please click on my account profile here and check out my breakfastary 'blog thingy.
author: Brian M.

description: Do not order the chorizo. It's terrible. It seemed more life ground pork with almost no seasoning. I ordered a breakfast burrito. With egg and chorizo. It was mediocre at best. I came early about 9am. The taste was fine but not really what I expected. I was disappointed while eating it. However 4 hours later my bowels told me a different story. I got sick. The only other thing j ate all day was my oatmeal at 5am. Which I eat everyday. I was sick all night. I will not be back.
author: Terese P.

description:
So I bought a flask. Yeah, yeah, big whoop. Everyone has a flask. But does everyone have an 18 oz flask? No, everyone does not. That's not even a flask - that's a party. Until the next day, anyway, because no one is meant to drink 18 ounces of vodka in four hours. And then: punishment. Headaches upon headaches. Nauseated stomach. What to do?

Grub down on some chilaquiles and horchata, por supuesto. Gooey cheese, eggs, salsa, onions, peppers, chiles, tortilla chips, with some beans and crema on the side? Uh, hello, hangover. Wait no, I meant goodbye, hangover. Seriously, no hangover can withstand the mighty power of the chilaquiles. Or the ferocious hydrating justice of Chava's excellent horchata. Once restored I also snarfed a bite of the birria del horno, which was glorious. 

Some people swear by burritos to cure their nighttime sins. Me? I swear by Chava's chilaquiles.
author: Corinna K.

description: I had pozole shared queso fundido the rice and beans are authentic homemade ...the arroz con leche I took home...handmade tortillas...and not expensive at all ....yummy reminds me of the food back in EAST LA...
author: Andrea G.

description:
Had an outrageously good bowl of menudo here a couple of months ago, so made a repeat visit. Unfortunately the second impression wasn't as good -- although well-washed (no wet doggy smell here) the menudo (callo only + plus a few small fragments of pato de puerco -- no libro or cuajo to be found in the bowl) Shorty's bowl been overcooked leaving it sort of flabby, and what was a well-seasoned richly flavored broth the first time around was muted and bland. It left me wondering if they prepared a large pot on Saturday, left it simmering all day, and then reheated it again on Sunday. 

This time I tried the birria en caldo. The broth was very flavorsome, but the meat content was somewhat skimpy compared to competing restaurants in the area. The meat did taste and appear to be chivo (goat) as promised, but had undergone the extra and probably unnecessary step of having been completely stripped from the bones which made confirmation difficult. 

A major plus to this place is the hand-pressed tortillas, with the masa being patted  into balls by the tortillera's young assistant, and then given a good squeeze in a wooden tortilla press. The second batch we got could have used a bit more time on the comal to bring the corny goodness out, but they were still 17 steps above factory-produced.
author: Ed T.

description:
Liked Chava's better at the old location (18th Street) but something changed when they made their move to da Mission. I think it is the "birds of a feather flock together" effect.... but some of the birds just can't fly well.

Heuvos Rancheros, tacos, salsa = good. As many reviews report the tortillas are awesome, but man can not live by tortillas alone.

Menudo (the soup not the band) is supposed to be great, I just can't stomach tripe. Kinda a family run joint, it is just A-OK
author: Matsuo U.

description: Where to begin, being Mexican I am quite opinionated on cultural foods, especially those whom try to mimick and Americanize food. However, chavas is as genuine as it gets. Their caldo de res made me feel like a 5 year old in my parents kitchen, the mix of kumbia-kingz and jenni-rivera took me back a decade. This place was great. Home made tortillas and the waitreses were exceptional!
author: Gisell I.

description: Loved everything about this place! Fast/friendly service, delicious food, and very authentic dishes! As a transplant So Cal girl, I am very picky when it comes to good Mexican food in the Bay. I can honestly say this place is delicious and authentic and I am definitely coming back for more! Do yourself a favor; Don't order a burrito, and actually try something new. I promise it is worth it.
author: Candace R.

description:
Had dinner here Saturday night. The food was generally good, the tongue was very good but the goat soup was mediocre, kind of tough and salty. Definitely not as good people other people said it was. 

Didn't speak Mexican, so many miscommunications were made. My friend's quesadilla was somehow replaced with a stack of tortillas.

Sangria was very nice.
author: George X.

description:
I landed at Chava's because Chavita's (Mission near Chavez) ran out of birria, according to my friend who was born and raised in the mission Chavita's is incomparable. The two places are not own by the same folks even though the similarity in names may suggest that. 
Food: Birria: I went here specifically for birria (goat stew). It was fine, but I've had better broths. The meat was plentyful and tortillas were hand made, fresh and tasty. The portion was large enough to take half home. I would give the birria a 7 out of 10 in comparison to other birrias I've had. Chips: They serve you free chips and salsa. The salsa was delicious, but the chips were stale.
Service: Fast and friendly.
author: M R.

description:
Good, solid and authentic Mexican meals.  Sides of rice and beans have excellent flavor.
Good enchiladas, chile rellenos.  Great tacos.  Chile verde is better at San Jalisco.  Salsa a little heavy on the cumin.

REVISION: on further review... chile verde as good or better than San Jalisco... first time may have just been unlucky!
author: Josh K.

description:
This place was not originally on my list of Mission burrito places to try, but we decided to come here when we saw some questionable characters outside of a place that was on our list. 

We were greeted warmly when we came in, and we immediately received some tasty chips and salsa. I really liked my giant glass bottle of Mexican Coke. We ordered one carnitas burrito and one carne asada burrito ... they were HUGE and we had to take some home because we just couldn't finish them. 

Great service, reasonable prices.
author: M B.

description:
I enjoyed going to a sit down, non-taqueria place in the mission for a change (although I adore taquerias as well, of course) to have a different style of food. Chips and salsa were fairly unexceptional, although the complimentary guacamole was a nice touch. They were out of chile colorado; I have no idea what the general availability on the menu is, but if you have your heart set on something, it might be best to check if it's available.

We went on a pretty warm day, and I can see how their soup specialties would be better on a colder, more blustery day. But as it was, the caldo de res was too salty for out tastes. I had the enchilada (chicken) and chile relleno combination plate. The hand-made tortillas were what stood out the most in the whole meal, and they were great. The chicken in both dishes was well prepared and tender, and the rice was pretty good (with carrots and peas in it). Altogether, though, everything added up to a kind of average meal. Our waitress was really friendly and I liked the dessert platter that is brought by, although we didn't try any of it.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Halloween 2009 @ 1PM

Before the cute little fairies and mini-Mike Myers come knocking on our door tonight, BF and I decided to hangout in the City to watch people in cool costumes and grab a Cubana Torta from "That's It" (as featured on Anthony Bourdain's No Reservations.) This was put away for BF's dinner tonight after he saw the dishes at Chava's.

As tempting as the Cubana Torta was, I didn't want to tempt fate since I value my life. :)  BF and I stopped by at Chavas so I could eat something less artery clogging.

We started drooling when we saw other diners' platter of yummy Mexican food and we decided to stay for lunch.

DRINKS:
MIMOSA: (3 Stars)  Check out how ginormous this thing was!!! http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hkqph_Rn9-_4TzGNJLIpzw?select=eoxhM4yI2ypeAF-NSa2NMg
It's okay for a mimosa, It was strong enough that it got me tipsy plus I can't complain. This giant was only $4!http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hkqph_Rn9-_4TzGNJLIpzw?select=NE-iRfSMaoC9zSz_-wOUFg

FOOD:
QUESO FUNDIDO W/ CHORIZO: (5 Stars)  Super-hot in a heavy-cast skillet. Gooey, oily, cheezy and delish!  This load of melted cheese was bad enough but with chorizo--it's double bad but sooo good!  I had to take bites with Lactaid but I wish I  could have more. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hkqph_Rn9-_4TzGNJLIpzw?select=YK_0PzTyWlm9Gq_71qlPuw

Me: FRIED TILAPIA W/ MEXICAN RICE:  (2.5 Stars) A disappointment! The whole platter was flavorless. Just salty and nothing else! 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hkqph_Rn9-_4TzGNJLIpzw?select=4KlVHJGeNXc4ivKWJYJiXg http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hkqph_Rn9-_4TzGNJLIpzw?select=EUNiXZ25ZGXcuTHR5Za6iA

BF:  CHILE RELLENO W/ RICE & BEANS: (4.5 Stars)  YUMM-O!!!! Eventhough I didn't order this this time, I've had Chile Relleno at Chava's before and it was delicous! BF reported that he could feel the tang and kick in his chile which complimented the rice and beans.  BF was happy with his meal. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hkqph_Rn9-_4TzGNJLIpzw?select=kYq2drD6271FcfcIVq54jQ
 
FREE HOT FRESH CORN TORTILLA: (6 Stars) We enjoyed watching the woman at the counter  flattening fresh balls of masa in the wooden tortilla maker then grilling them. The result:  DELICIOUS, PIPING-HOT, FRESH CORN TORTILLAS. BF and I were like circus performers juggling the hot tortillas and made a meal out of them!

FREE CHIPS AND SALSA: (4.5 Stars) Fried chip and fresh spicy salsa. Addicting!

OVERALL: (4.5 Stars) 
Chavas is a great place to experience the authentic Mexican food and what the Mission has to offer.  The staff were friendly in this hole in the wall. We had fun watching them dance to Latin music in their cat outfit during Halloween.  

FINAL TAB: $38 including  2 Diet Cokes, Mimosa, tax before tip. 

I am a big fan of the Mish and so fortunate that I'm just a BART-ride away from this food heaven!
author: Leah E.

description: Really good authentic Mexican food but the lady keeps on forgetting my agua de fresa! Hahaha
author: Jessica A.

description: Came here because of the four star ratings and was truly disappointed. This place is not authentic food. We had the order of chilaquiles which was suppose to consist of 3 eggs, based on the menu description. What we got instead were chips dipped in some sort of sauce, a sprinkle of eggs, a bunch of shopped onions and and a spoon of sour cream. They were bland and looked unappetizing. When we shared our disappointment with, what appeared to be the owner, she expressed that this was one of their most famous dishes, widely enjoyed by white folks. If you are looking for true delicious and authentic Mexican food, this is not the place to go.
author: Jen A.

description: FAKE chips. This is one of my criterion for a good taqueria, they must make fresh chips! This place gets those yellow costco-y chips- blech! I came up with this theory though: they hate tortillas. They make their own corn tortillas (which are ok, not great) so I guess it wouldn't work that well to cut those up and fry them for chips since they're thicker and whatnot. So since they don't buy tortillas for their food, they dont have any to chop up and fry for chips. Uncool.The chicken Mole was ok, a tad sweeter than I like but to the average palate it would probably be quite good. Oh, I think I remember liking the rice and beans but they were skimpy on those.
author: Emma H.

description: End up in this place since EL TAQUERIA was close, food was awesome and customer service was impeccable. I highly recommend this place for MEXICAN food. I believe one of the gems on the Mission district.
author: Oberlin M.

description: We didn't like the feel of this place. Not that it was too sketchy, just cheesy. (Well, there was that homeless woman sprinkling her chips with beer and staring maliciously at me...) The birria, which we came for, was pretty good but not great. Ill stick to Gallardos when it reopens.
author: Paul K.

description: Chavas use to be the destination point when I wanted authentic Mexican food. I haven't been in over a year since moving to Concord but yesterday, I wanted really good menudo and posole for breakfast, but instead I decided to try their "special" beef soup. I should have stuck with what I originally wanted. The beef was hard and chewy, the vegetable weren't good and it was salty. My husband had a carnitas burrito with lots of fat and he felt it was old meat. The orchata, guac and tortillas were yummy but the kicker was, our bill was almost $30 with a soup that we misunderstood as being on "special" when it was the "special of the day" .  Disappointed.
author: Phelia R.

description:
Chavas' ain't all that folks! Super cheap, lots of food but really dirty place. As a native SF'er and growing up in the outter mission, this place was LOUD - a junkbox spitting out of tune mexican rancheras. Glasses, plates, silverwear are dirty.  Took my dad there for breakfest - his pick, not mine - his drinking glass had lipstick marks around the rim. The table was dirty with greasy handprints.
Oh, the food. chips are tastless, thick and greasy with lots of salt. Eggs ranchero - runny eggs smothered in a very watered-down-tomatoe sauce.
Beans cooked in manteca (LARD) and way overcooked rice. Everything was greasy, dirty, and never again visit.
author: A G.

description:
I've been coming here since I was little, and before they switched locations. I've been a big fan of their Birra and quesadillas for a long time. There is nothing better then a rolled up homemade tortilla and a big 'ol heaping bowl of birra or menudo. They both have great flavor. And the quesadilla is just cheesy goodness. Their plates are pretty big, so you can share if you really want to.

They only take cash, which kinda sucks if you only bring your debit card everywhere you go, but there are the big banks around within walking distance.
author: Em C.

description:
So, I was looking for a good place to get a bowl of Birria de Chivo last Sunday and turned to yelp to decide my future. I gotta say, on this particular occasion, it came through huge! the interior is kind of a grungy, hole-in-the-wall type of scene, which lead us to believe that the food was likely very good. We went ahead and ordered the Queso Fundido  with Chorizo (about $8), the Birria de Chivo (about $11), and the super burrito de pollo ($6). 

The queso fundido (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hkqph_Rn9-_4TzGNJLIpzw?select=57rZocNnMKCK_HM66VK9Ng) came out first with some homemade tortillas (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hkqph_Rn9-_4TzGNJLIpzw?select=-54DQbQE3vxhArpL6L6otw). It was so cheesy, melty and delicious and the chorizo set it off perfectly. I found myself mixing in some of the serranos from the table and, whaaaaammmmyyy! Awesome, fattening, greasy dish. The wifey's burrito was pretty weak. Still not into the whole beans and rice in the burrito thing and the chicken was just okay. That being said, we knew that she ordered wrong beforehand and would have went to Farolito up the street for a real burrito. But, we came here and mostly because I wanted some birria. This version was one of the better ones that I have had. It was more of a soup (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hkqph_Rn9-_4TzGNJLIpzw?select=uugbWG8LgKoV-iMckRAiWA) than a stew like some places serve it and was huge! The broth was a little thinner, which made it easy to eat, but still had plenty of spice and flavor to it. I added some more serrano's, but that's just because i like it to hurt a little. It was piping hot, so the chilies, onions, and cilantro cooked right in. The goat (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hkqph_Rn9-_4TzGNJLIpzw?select=kvprNcSgrVOtpok5Lzp5Kg) was so tender that it was falling off the (amazingly) few bones in the bowl. They must have been keeping all of the bones in the pot for flavor because goats are some boney creatures. The meat was not quite as gamey as I usually like but it was still very flavorful and I really enjoyed it. 

They have a pretty large menu, so this was just our first visit. We will have to make it back for the chicken soup, the pozole, and maybe even the menudo (para la cruda).
author: Miguel V.

description:
Nothing helps warm the soul from this recent apocalyptic cold weather better than some great soup.  And pozole is just one of those soups that do the job.  So, I headed to Chava's on a very brisk and nippy Sunday night for their popular pozole.  I wasn't the only one with this brilliant idea, as all of Chava's patrons were also slurping on bowls of pozole.

I have been in love with pozole ever since my Tijuanian ex-coworker brought me in some of her mom's homemade pozole a couple years ago.  For those who don't know, pozole is a chile-based soup with pork and hominy.  Add tons of chopped onions, cilantro and lime to enhance the hearty soup.  Typically, pig's feet are also used in pozole, which can deter some people from eating it, but growing up in a very Chinese household, pig's feet are no foreign object to me.

Chava's $8.25 bowl of pozole is gigantic and can leave your bladder on the verge of bursting.  It's chock full of meat, pig's feet, and hominy.  Every spoonful is loaded with goodies.  Although the soup is a bright hue of red, it's not too spicy either.

We also tried their carnitas platter, which didn't do it for us.  The meat was bland and not crispy, the way carnitas should be.  Their homemade tortillas were good and we also liked the complimentary chips with salsa and guacamole.

Note: Just come here for the soup.  Pozole, menudo, birria, caldo de pollo, oh my!
author: Diane L.

description:
Super cheap, super bomb Mexican food, great service, right next to Bart. How can you go wrong? 
Also, those tortillas are the shizzzzzz!
author: Angela S.

description: Decent food, served quickly but sometimes absentmindedly.  No dish stood out as worth a return trip.
author: Brent P.

description: Tacos were all right, they were hella greasy. The lengua aka Cow tongue for white people was good. But I had better, only came here because La Taqueria was closed.
author: Fidel M.

description: Best place to have a good Mexican lunch on the weekends (in SF). The Birria and Menudo here are amazing. They have had made tortillas on the weekends. Weekends are also busy but worth the wait. The two negatives are 1) they only take cash and 2) parking is hard, as it is in the Mission. Completely worth it though!
author: Liliana C.

description:
Real Mexican Food.  Recommend the Chiliquiles and Huevos Rancheros for breakfast but really all of their food is good.  They also have some of the best agua frescas around. 
The food was better way back when it was 18th Street but it's still really good today.
author: Mikecool E.

description:
Note : this review is for the chava's directly across the street from the BART station on Mission street.  Travelled out here for lunch and back to Montgomery/Sutter in one hour.
Excellent Birria de Chivo soup today!  the grande bowl was loaded with earthy goat meat stewed in red chile. Yummy. Came with a 3 home made corn tortilla's. I could not finish all of the food.
Enough food for two light eaters. Comes with a big bowl of non greasy corn chips, with a bowl of red chile salsa AND some home made salsa fresca and a small side of chunky fresh guacamole. I washed this meal down with a large glass of Jimaica. $11.65 w/o tip.
Muy Bueno. 
The menu is pretty large, so I'll for sure be returning. 
Decor: Clean , nice airy well lit place, 100 ft from the BART station.  
Musica : Mex bolero's pumpin' softly.
Customer service: friendly and excellent.
author: Bert K.

description: Chava's restaurant is great! They have hand made tortillas! I love ordering the chile verde and steak quesadillas. The carnitas tacos are delicious and the portions are large. I love the free chips and salsa too!
author: Adriana H.

description:
The owners are the BEST. They treat you very special; make you feel warm and welcome. The food is "tipica" and delicious, not like other Mexican restaurants whose menu is anything, but.
 
The service is friendly and courteous. The menudo and pozole are my favorites.

However, everything you order leaves you wanting more and is tantalizing to the palate. Elba and Marcelo's humility, as owner's, makes their restaurant proud to offer the BEST Mexican cuisine.

I recommend this restaurant to anyone who enjoys delicious food and not spending a bundle to get it. Prices are extremely reasonable.

Over 20 years in the community, Chava's holds its ground!

ricky c.
author: Ricky C.

description: The first was that the guacamole wasn't that well prepared, not salty enough, kind of tasteless. the plate I had, the chile verde was also not that flavorful, one piece of the meat was just fat. But the serving size was pretty decent. Also there was a lack of napkins. There might be better dishes here but eh, could be better.
author: Joshua F.

description: I saw the line at la taqueria and headed here. Turned out to be a wise choice. Two tacos with carnitas and carne asada. The meats were both very flavorful and as good as any I have had. I also had a beef enchilada mole. The mole was a bit sweet for my taste but very flavorful. All in all very very good 4.5 stars. Slight deduction for no salsa bar though the red sauce they bring you is excellent and a little too sweet a mole. I would not hesitate to come back and skip the lines at el ferolito and la taqueria..
author: John S.

description: This place is pure math.  Somehow by adding chilaquiles/horchata to a violent hangover the hangover disappears.  Science is amazing!  Sadly I live in colder climes but when I next return I'm gonna eat the butt out of some chilaquilies/birria.
author: Kyle K.

description: Certainly not top of the line huevos, but it cured my hangover after a fun night.  Cash only.
author: David P.

description: By far the Fish Taco that I had at Chavas was the best I've  ever had. The Talapia fish was grilled perfectly and each bite was delicious.  I normally order the Pozole with the fresh made tortillas. But I have definitely found my new favorite.... Talapia Fish Tacos!
author: Suzie Q.

description:
January was a month of indulgence, and Henry V and I were ready to enjoy the last day of this sinful month with some final gluttonous moments before transitioning to restorative February.  

We started with a giant pulpy mimosa with a cherry on top, the texture of pulp and the artificial sweetness of cherry prepping our tongues for fresh conversations and sweet-but-so-not-good-for-you gossip.

The crunch of tortilla chips with guacamole followed along with laughter at all that was lost in translation as we bantered with our server in broken Spanish.

It should have ended with chile rellenos and enchiladas that were inhaled too quickly.

But it didn't.

Thick, creamy flan was quietly consumed as we suppressed sounds that would be more appropriate between sheets instead of spoons.
author: anjou k.

description: The food was ok, but the service was terrible. They messed up our order more than once and the waitress was really rude to us. This place is mediocre. If you want Mexican food go somewhere else. It is a waste of time here.  Ps: there are roaches
author: Diane L.

description: My boyfriend and I come here on Sundays pretty often for the birria. It is extremely good/crave worthy with chopped onion, cilantro, and lemon slices for toppings and a basket of fresh fluffy tortillas. We split one with a side of beans and rice and are very full. Its the perfect Mexican brunch for $20 (without tip)!
author: SJ P.

description:
Perhaps my number one go-to for brunch in the Mission.

Cheap: hard to spend over $10. Do *not* order anything beyond your main dish, as it will be much more than you'll be able to finish. Plus, they even give free guac and salsa with the chips.

Never a wait. In fact, I've never seen it close to crowded.

Easy to sit outside, right on the sidewalk! If you don't see chairs, just ask, they'll set them up. 

Friendly service, with lots of smiles and liberal use of "amigo" and "honey."

And damn solid food. It won't win awards, but when you just need a big mess of rice, beans, and something smothered in sauce and cheese, this is exactly what you wanted.
author: Jesse F.

description:
I shall never, ever, come back to this place.
I ordered chile verde, which was my favorite dish, even when the original Chava's,
Was at 18th. St.
When I got my order it had, in plain view, pieces of steel wool, that I suspect was
used to wash the pot in which the meal was cooked. When I pointed that out to the
waitress, she did not take any action, no even take the plate back.
I ended up paying for something I did not eat.
It's a pity, since it was my favorite place.
author: Eduardo R.

description:
Pozole de Puerco, hand made tortillas, mixed fruit agua fresca! Today I enjoyed my 2nd visit to Chavas even more than my 1st visit just last week.

When I saw that they serve poloze, I knew I had to come back to try it. I have eaten pozole only once before so I am no expert, but today's pozole at Chavas was the most delightful, delicious, "tastes like Mama made it" brew of chunks of tender pork, hominy and pigs feet that I could imagine.  Please don't fear pigs feet.  They are quite delicious.

The restaurant was a bit busy today but the service was excellent and my waitress coached me on how to use the dish of garnishes that came with the pozole. She also seemed delighted that I was so happy with my meal.

The bowl is huge! I brought a good bit home with me and just now enjoyed a 2nd bowl and have enough for one more bowl (breakfast tomorrow morning!).

Next time I go  I would like to try the caldo de pollo if I can stop myself from ordering pozole again.
author: Marcia P.

description: Chunky soup is "the soup that eats like a meal"? Puh-leeze. Get the caldo pollo soup here and good luck finishing all that food.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
So? How do you say "handi-wipe in Spanish? 

LOL Contrary to what the media will tell you, the best Mexican restaurants in the Mission are the ones with dirty tables and flies. 

What Chavas lacks in upscale (think: Marina) yuppy plastic decor, it makes up in excellent food and a true Mexican eating experience. Hell, everytime I go to Chavas, the place is always packed with locals drinking their Coronas and eating their tostadas. 

Chavas is well worth the $$$ when you're looking to satisfy the hunger monster.
author: Black K.

description:
They have the BEST-EST beef soup I've ever had.....along with the homemade tortillas! YUM!!!!

Just a lil hard for parking...definitely worth the trip across the bridge.
author: Sharee g.

description: Always make time to go to Chava's when in San Fransisco. Best breakfast and their chicken mole is worth the trip alone.
author: Gary D.

description:
RIP the old Chava's. 

I have only returned to the new location several times, but the food even just isn't the same. So much of the charm of Chava's was the seediness of the place and how when you went in hungover on Sunday mornings (well, for me sober since I was a kid tagging along with my hungover parents), the whole place felt like family.

That all disappeared in the fire :(

Fortunately we've found a new home in Los Jarritos.
author: Miranda R.

description: I needed some chicken soup today and found Chava's on Yelp.  I got some Caldo de Pollo to go and when I got home, put the chopped onions, cilantro and squeezed in some lemon juice.  Just what I needed.  The Caldo was rich and flavorful, big chunks of vegetables, 3 good size pieces of chicken.  All in all very satisfying.
author: Kristina V.

description:
This is the first place I tried chilaquiles, and it's still my favorite place to eat them.  The tortillas are soft and handmade.  

Don't expect prompt service, water refills, or any substitutions to ever be remembered.
author: Amy D.

description: Oh, the chicken mole! Great tortillas. And the caldos are excellent, as well.
author: Sharman G.

description:
Ooohhhhh - YUM! 

I didn't want a big lunch - so I had a chicken enchilada (home made tortilla and shredded chicken breast), refried beans, Spanish rice and salad. It was sooo good, I ate the whole thing and nearly licked the plate clean. 

Oh yes, I was a little piggy and I'll do it again.
author: Mercy B.

description: My husband & I originally wants to go to a different Mexican taqueria which we heard from the news was the best Mexican taqueria, so we went & the line was out the door and we left and on the same block we saw this Chava's Taqueria it looks nice but not crowded so we went in & ordered fish burrito & crispy beef tostado w/ rice & refried beans.  The food was very tasty and delicious.  The place was clean and nice.  By the way, they only accept cash, give this place a try, you would not regret it :D
author: Belle L.

description:
If you are having hard times choosing a mexican restaurant in Mission, go straight to this one. It might look a bit ordinary from the outside, but the food is gorgeous. 

Let's put it this way: suppose that you gather a number of mexican (inspired, not desperate :-) ) housewives who can really cook in a huge open kitchen. What would you get out of them? fantastic food ... those sick thoughts assaulted my mind after having admired a cute old lady kneading dough in front of my eyes and serve the resulting flour tortillas to us in a covered pot right after having steamed them. 

Everything we had, starting from the corn nachos, the various spicy sauces lying on the table and the guacamole (surely the lightest, maybe the best I have ever tried) were perfect. So were the beans, the rice, the quesadillas and, especially, my garlic fish fillet, which was cooked in a marvellous sauce made with green peppers, garlic, cilantro, mushrooms and tomatoes.  

Portions are huge, prices really cheap and the atmosphere is familiar.
author: Andrea L.

description:
It was Friday the weather was close to perfect and I wanted a Burrito Damn it!

I snatched up one of m friends at work and we vented a whole weeks worth crap in the 2 block walk.  We needed beers.

I walked up and there was plenty of outdoor seating and the line was moving quickly, and from what I could see the beer was ice cold. 
The food smelled and looked amazing! I got the chicken burrito with hot salsa and all the fixin's and one of the beers I was eyeing.

My first bite was heaven! I was in love.

So after a bomb burrito, beer, yummy corn chips and an extended bitch session I was happy as a clam. I will definatley be back!
author: Alicia K.

description: Good food, nothing outrageous (except for the huge portions), very friendly people. Their soups are HUGE! Broth was good. Milanesa de carne was nice - not fatty at all, crispy. Everything is cooked to order so none of that counter taqueria stuff here, which to me is a good thing because I like my food cooked fresh. It was a nice place to try, but with so many other places in the area and in the city to try, I don't see myself coming back anytime soon.
author: Jonas T.

description: A true taste of Mexico... as in, the burrito went right through me.
author: Danny C.

description: Our place for my regular pozole fix.  Friendly.  She also tolerates my completely broken Spanish without any drama.
author: Chris E.

description:
I go in search of heuvos rancheros.

I've been seeking the best heuvos rancheros on Saturday monings.  There are dozens of restaurants within walking distance of my home that have some variation on what can be the perfect hearty breakfast and Chavas is among the ones I'll return to.  

They start every diner off with the expected tortilla chips and fresh salsa but they also bring complimentary guacamole - nicely made and great to nibble on as I tell waitress I already know what I want: huevos rancheros.  

I often bring a book or paper to breakfast but it isn't a good idea here.  The jukebox is loud and the conversation louder.  So I usually practice my miserable Spanish which everyone but me is natively speaking.  This is a good sign - I lke it when I go to a Mexican joint and everyone but me is latino - same for other ethnic restaurants - like when I go to Yummy Yummy and I' the only non-Vietnamese there.  

The heuvos come out with more cheese than I generally like on this dish but the eggs are just right - runny yolks but whites that are set but not overcooked.  The sides of refried beans, rice and e nicely made ranchero sauce is very good though.  There is a steaming plate of tortillas to help scoop up the goods.  The coffee is hot and strong.  

While it still isn't the best huevos rancheros I've had it is still very good and I'll be back to this comfy Mission family restaurant.
author: Jon R.

description: Got a wet burrito and there was barely any meat inside!! Waste of money and I'm still hungry!
author: Fernando P.

description:
This is the best place to squelch a massive hangover.  There are two categories of dishes that take care of that job:

Soups: birria, caldo de res, caldo de pollo, menudo.  When your mouth is dry and needs meat flavored moisture, this is it.

Eggs: chilaquiles, machaca, huevos rancheros, huevos a la mexicana, it's all pretty fucking good.

Extra points for the complimentary guacamole that they give you with the chips (not a ton of it, but something is better than nothing), and the fresh tortillas, which I always feel bad about wasting (seriously, who can eat all of the tortillas and all of a dish?  That's a lot of grub).
author: David C.

description:
Every time I or my brothers go up to visit the Familia up in the Bay Area, its a must that we go have our breakfast at Chava's. 

I've had several great dishes there but I pretty much stick to 2 of them when I visit...

1) the Machaca breakfast 
2) the Birria

but man, I love their HUGE Tortillas too, & they come very handy when I'm having my Birria Soup.

I too still remember the OG Chava's on 18th st. & yes there is something missing from the current Chava's location that the OG location had, but the food is still great.

BTW, I leave L.A. at 4am soo I can get there & meet my cousins there for breakfast, kinda crazy don't y'all think, lol...=-D
author: Cesar D.

description: The service here is fantastic and the locals that frequent seem cool. I've only had the soup all 4 times I've been. Caldo Pollo / Chicken Soup is the best thing in the world. A giant bowl of soup with 3 sections of chicken on the bone (the leg is a little difficult to free the meat from with a fork and spoon but its doable). Flavor is amazing and its served with rice and tortillas. And you can have a beer with your meal! My bill was $13 for lunch: soup and one beer. Not bad.
author: Morgan A.

description:
This has quickly become one of my favorite spots in the Mission and probably my favorite breakfast spot in the city.  They have a wide assortment of traditional authentic Mexican dishes on their menu including Caldos de Albondigas (vegetable soup with meatballs) , birria (beef soup) , pozele ( chicken or pork soup with hominy) , mole (chicken with sweat mole sauce) and more!
The staff is also very friendly and they make everyone feel at home.  If you want to fill your stomach on a Sunday morning after a long night of partying this is definitely the place.
author: Katie G.

description:
Huevos Rancheros. Go Hungry, or be sensible and split a HUGE plate of huevos rancheros with a buddy. It will still be plenty of food. The amount of food served is completely over the top. 

After reading all these reviews below, I decided to go with my food partner to sample both the chilaquales and huevos rancheros. They were both really good, although it was true the huevos were a little heavy on the cheese. If you don't like your huevos messy and a little soupy, then these are not for you. The chilaquales got good reports, but I was too busy with my own food to even go there. 

I concluded that they have the best tortillas that I have tasted in the Mission. We sat at the bar and watched someone with a huge bucket of masa freshly prepare tortilla after tortilla. All of which puffed up to fluffy heights and were whisked away into to tortilla baskets. Yum.

The amazing value at this place was for the gigantic bowl of freshly squeeze, incredibly yummy orange juice they brought us for a mere $3.50. Again, big enough for two people with straws. 

The soups looked very well done. I will be back to maybe add another star to this review. It was a little loud, but fun and the waitress was sweet.
author: Megan P.

description: What do you feed someone who thinks it's ok to drink 18 oz of vodka in a few hours the day after? Chilaquiles! Crispy strips of tortilla in a casserole like mixture of eggs, cheese, peppers, onions, chiles and pork with red sauce. Even mr grumpy brightened a bit at the sight. I liked this restaurant, clean and cheerful staff, an older woman pressing homemade tortillas in the open kitchen. I tried the birria, a goat version of carnitas. Gamey and rich, crunchy and fatty, served with rice, beans and those tortillas. About $10, a huge portion, enough for at least two more meals. Onion, cilantro, radishes and oranges are brought as sides, chips and two salsas complimentary. Families were popping in before their soccer games and local elders breakfasted here as well.i tried the carrot juice, good, and the undead enjoyed his horchata. Strawberry agua fresca was refreshing and fruity.  About $50 for a family of four eating the most expensive entrees, which is to say cheap...and great!
author: Kelly K.

description:
(It's NOT a taqueria!  If you want a burrito go to a taqueria!)

1. Machaca con Huevos!
2. Birria
3. home made tortillas
4. Caldo de Res

The taco/enchilada/chili relleno part of the menu is good, but nothing to dance on the table about.  Order any of the egg dishes (I just love the machaca) or the big bowls of soup, and a giant glass of carrot or orange juice, and you'll be a happy, stuffed muchacho.  And their corn tortillas are the real thing.
author: Rob B.

description:
Closer to a 2.5 on the food alone. I was expecting a hearty chicken noodle soup to help with this annoying summer cold, and what I got was some broth with good veggies, but whole chicken pieces. There was more skin and bone than actual meat. I picked off the best chunks of meat I could, but it ended up being much less than I was expecting. You do get a decent amount of tortillas and rice on the side, but I was looking for soup, not make your own burritos.

Extra 0.5 star because I do feel better today. Not 100%, but getting there.
author: Jason B.

description:
The food is decent. The chips, salsa and guac are so good that I get full before my actual meal arrives. I'm taking away a star and a half for the god awful louder than hell music in there. I had to repeat my order 3 x
because the waitress couldn't hear me,  and believe it when I say that
I don't have a soft voice. There is no possibility of a conversation when you eat here. Order take out and you'll be happy.
author: Cindy J.

description:
Two words-- Nash Bridges.  Yup, the Don Johnson SF crime show.  I first found out about Chavas from a little bio on Cheech Marin.  He said Chava's is where he goes for authentico mexican food while filming in The City.  

That was a long time ago when Chava's was at it's 18th street location.  Everything was so good-- just like Nana used to make-- crispy shredded beef tacos, enchiladas, mole, good chips & salsa.  aye dios!  mexican comfort food at its best.  

Unforch, there was a fire, and so went Chava's until this location opened.  Sadly, *something* was lost.  It's something that made Chava's special wasn't at the new location.   The food was lacking.  I was sad.  

The last time the mrs & I ate there, she didn't want to finish her meal.  She took one bite of her taco and grease poured from the meat.  Not dripped-- POURED.  Not meat juice--Grease. We tried to pat the meat dry, but as napkins piled up, the gross factor climbed.

3 stars because the type of Mexican food still matters. It's the real deal.
author: Pea H.

description:
Anyone who knows me well knows that there is nothing I like better for breakfast than fresh tortillas with beans and fried eggs. Unfortunately, not every Mexican place in town has fresh tortillas. Chavas does. YUM!
My friend and I ordered two huge plates of food. I had the Huevos Rancheros and a Carrot Juice which came in a huge glass with a side class full of Ice. my friend ordered an American Coke, and by the end of the meal we had both ordered a couple of Mexican Cokes as well... The entire bill for breakfast, including tip was under thirty dollars. Very reasonably priced and good food served in HUGE portions. This is my new favorite local place for tortillas and eggs because it is just steps away from the BART station.
author: Kimberley M.

description:
Live in Fremont and came to SF for the day with my two teens,toddler, hubby and brother.. Stopped here because I checked yelp real quick and found it to be highly rated....

Greeted with some great Mexican hospitality by the ladies working there-so so nice and helpful with my kids!! Loved the chips, salsa and guacamole!! 
We had their beer, lime and salt ICE cold drinks-Chavla what we call it in our hood...

Place was clean and food was right on!! My toddler ate his whole plate of rice and beans which he hardly does... He loved it  Liked that they cook right there in front of us so no funny business-not that I expected that from this place since they seem to take great pride in their restaurant.. Great place for familes!! Recommended highly!
author: Viviana C.

description:
Well I went here after my 6 year old son nixed La Taqueria.  How can La Taqueria be a Mexican restaurant without serving rice? he asked.  I guess he had a point, although rice is not a big concern for me.

I almost walked out of Chava's after going in.  In the heart of the Mission, and were not many people there.  But the staff seemed friendly so I stayed.  And all in all it was a pretty good place:

Hand made tortilla's: 5 stars
Chips served with guacamole and fresh salsa, gratis: 4.5 stars
Decent aguas frescas: 4 stars
Pretty good prices: 4.5 stars
The rice and beans were okay. 3 stars.
The chile verde had a seasoning mix unusual to me.  Also had chunks of potatoe.  3.75 stars.
Service: 4 stars.

I still have reservations about their level of business which seemed low.  Have concerns about food that might not be the freshest.  I guess it is an article of faith that they mind the proper preservation of food.  Putting that issue to the side, a pretty good restaurant.
author: G. W.

description:
FYI, cash only place!

First off, the food is good, I LOVE that they use traditional quesadilla cheese for the quesadilla's, SO good! The rest of the menu is equally great! Guacamole is on the weak side as are the chips. The ladies TOTALLY remind me of members of my family and our SUPER sweet, nice and funny as hell!! LOVE this place and the staff!!!
author: Rob L.

description:
Chava's is wonderful.  The food portions are gigante!  And I enjoy the little salsita tray they bring to your table when you order your food.  I love the feel and the clientele--I only hear my native Espanol-- a que bueno!

Buen Provecho!
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description:
I used to eat at Chava's all the time when they were on 18th street., but got out of the habit when that location closed. 

I've had many very good items on the menu over the years: carne asada, a spare rib stew (can't remember the name and is usually mostly bones), lengua en salsa, chile verde, and chilaquiles. I love their homeade corn tortillas too.

This place represents a typical good Mexican restaurant in the Mission, give it a try. Now I'm getting hungry.
author: Yvette K.

description:
It has a modest atmosphere, but who cares, the food was amazing and cheap!! Plus we're talking about the Mission district on Mission street, any more upscale and it'll be filled with douche bags. 

Service was great too considering they seemed a bit under staffed, but everything was served quickly and steaming hot! 

I got the pork in Chile Verde sauce which came with rice, beans and 2 steaming hot corn tortillas. It's was perfection! The meat just melted in my mouth, the sauce tasted like it was slow simmered with love for a couple of days. 

My BF, got the chicken in mole sauce which was also cooked to perfection! the mole sauce was just savory and delicious! 

Also, the Agua fresca were just so fresh and tasty! 

Must try this place!
author: Julio A.

description:
Five stars for the chicken soup. FABULOUS chicken soup. Big bowl. Giant chunks of chicken (bone-in), potatoes, carrots and other goodies. Then on the side, they bring you bowls of rice, onions, chilis and cillantro, so that you can add them to whatever degree you want. (And I want a lot.) It's just so good. Sometimes the jukebox will be playing, and that's a plus. The staff has always been very nice, even though I can't always communicate with them that well with the language differences. Long-timers will remember the original Chava's several blocks away that burned down. Boy... that place was just crazy, with how tightly-packed the tables were and the murky lighting. I did like how they had outdoor seating though. This location used to be another Taqueria San Jose (like the one which is now still across the street), but once Chava's burned down, they ended up taking over this location... so there must be a connection between the restaurant owners or something. (As an aside, my favorite cheap steak tacos, outside of a taco truck, are at Taqueria San Jose.) So anyways -- I'd highly recommend trying this place out. If it's a nice day, get one of the tables by an open window, order the soup and a beer, and sit there and people-watch as you enjoy your delicious and incredibly filling meal.
ps: I added a pic of the soup to the Chava's description.
author: Zoe H.

description:
The first time I went to Chava's was after a trip to a cheap fabric outlet next door.  It was the weekend before el dia de los muertos, and I had a hankering for some mole.  I had only had mole once before almost ten years ago, but even w/out a recent basis for comparison, I must say that I was pleased.  

The next time I had the fried tilapia, and was not put off by the grease.  Yesterday I took my parents there, and my dad had this wonderful plate of fajitas, and my mom had some yummy beef tacos.  I had the grilled fish which was also good.  This is not the best food I have ever had, but it may be the best Mexican food I've ever had in a restaurant.
