A note on the atmosphere: Whenever I go there alone I like to sit at the counter and watch the ladies behind the glass make some of their fabulous tortillas.  Otherwise you can sit at the tables and take in the Diego Rivera-style murals.  Oh, and I love to stare at the waitresses.  A couple of them favor bizarrely frosted hair and jeans so tight you wonder how they keep up their bumble-bee bustle when it's really busy.  If you hear a loud rip, someone's jeans may have busted (given the enormity of the portions, it may just be your pair).

Everyone here is very friendly, food is good, and the place is clean.
author: CAKE E.

description:
First of all, the hand made tortillas (come with everything) are SO FREAKIN good I crave them.  (You can even buy them "to go" in the morning).

Machaca and eggs (shredded beef and eggs, with peppers, onions and mushrooms) a great break from typical breakfast fare.

Menudo is great and this place is SO authentic, even for the Mission.  No burritos that I'm aware of.

Just mentioning those tortillas gives my Mexican huz a big fat stiffy.  I think we're going again today.
author: Enzo L.

description:
I thought this place keeps moving and I keep thinking Oh it's closed down and then I'll be randomly wandering around and suddenly I find it's most recent incarnation!  (And now I read from these reviews it's cuz the one on 18th St. by my old house BURNED DOWN in a FIRE!  I had no idea.  I'm so lame.  anyways)

it's all about the soup! soup! soup! and the little bowls of self-spicing provided.  

And the fresh handmade tortillas!  tortillas! tortillas! 

And all for breakfast! breakfast!  breakfast! 

Good stuff.  Go eat.  Be happy.
author: Robyn C.

description:
Back when I lived in Los Angeles, my father had an amazing knack for finding little hole-in-the-wall's that looked like there was no way you'd want to go inside, but once you had a taste of their food, you'd be constantly looking forward to going back.  Chava's is just that sort of place.

Considering that it is completely off the beaten trail, it is a testament to the food that there is always a LONG line at lunch.  They do your standard burrito fare, but also have wide-range of tasty Mexican dishes including a few out of the ordinary choices.  The food here reminds me of being a kid and living in Mexico, and the restaurant looks like it was literally lifted up in a twister in Jalisco and dropped down here.

The only question is why are tamales the special every single day?  I guess some questions there are just no answers to.
author: Trigby P.

description: Their chicken soup helped me get over the swine flu and best yet, it also reminded me of a combination of Mexican and Pho - Pho because they gave you onions, cilantro and lime to put in the soup. I can't wait to check out what else they have.
author: Alexandra M.

description:
Back when Chava's was still on Shotwell, I was a very regular patron.  Newly arrived in San Francisco, I was wowed by the exotic (goat, tripe and pig's feet in the various soups? amazing!), romanced by the vibrant execution of old standards (all the breakfast-y huevos dishes with the delicious dial turned to 11) and in awe of the tortilla-maker and the older patrons who tipped her on their way out.

Then, the fire wiped out this location, and Chava's was closed for so, so long.

When it reopened in its current location, something was missing.  The food was uninspired and bland.  We all joked that they lost their seasoned pots in the fire; whatever it was, I missed my old haunt, but eventually became an El Metate loyal instead.

With friends in town, we decided to do a birria run.  While still not an 11, I am once again happy to recommend Chava's to the community of foodies.
author: J P.

description: When I think of Chava's, I automatically think (and want) their Huevos Rancheros (solid yolk please).  The plate is gigantic, there are 2-3 eggs over 2 of their frisbee sized tortillas, smothered with their ranchera sauce and melted cheese.  It comes with refried beans and rice.  It's way too much food to eat by myself, so I split it with my sis.  On top of that, they provide free chips, salsa, and guacamole.  This is a great place for a hearty and flavorful breakfast.
author: Lesliegh H.

description: SOUP, SOUP, SOUP!!!!!!  Great soup place $12 bucks and 5 plates on the table damn this place is good!
author: David G.

description: I love Chavas. It is my go to place after Glide Church on Christmas day. The mix of people, the atmosphere, etc. I love the Chile rellenos. It isn't quite as good at the 17th and Shotwell place but still wonderful. The food is satisfying and delicious.
author: anne m.

description:
As a white kid, I grew up in southern California eating Mexican food from the get go. This is the only authentic Mex restaurant I have ever found in SF. Most of the rest are really El Salvadorean or Mex food for white people such Los Jarritos. This is the real thing.-Homemade tortillas. birria, soups like in the "old country" and frijoles refritos  to die for. The crispy tacos, the machaca, I could go on and on. Forget the decor, the service, even the cleanliness, it is all about the food here. Mexican heaven! 
I took my 87 year old father here. Even he was awed by the machaca!
author: sam t.

description: I was craving a Mexican breakfast and Chavas's seemed like the go to place for this. You are started off with crisp chips and a small side of salsa (could have been fresher) and guacamole (a bit watery). The huevos rancheros plate is huge...3 eggs...My only complaint is that everything was smothered in cheese. The handmade corn tortillas arrive in a basket and they are wonderful. One thing I have never seen..there is a bowl filled with long dried red chilies and long fresh green chilies on the table. Love the music and felt like I was in Mexico.
author: Bleep S.

description: Mmmmmm, love the weekend soups in the Mish.  Anthony got the birria, I got the posole (pork, of course), and I couldn't decide which one was better.  They are both fabulous... and HUGE... and the yelpers don't lie when they rave about the home-made, hand-shaped corn tortillas.  Hangover, be gone - Chava's has the cure!
author: Julie L.

description: One of my friends from San Francisco recommended this place and it was amazing. I was looking for good Mexican food in the city and this place definitely had it. It is right by the BART station in the Mission, so it's easy to get to. It is definitely true Mission style food, but that is really a good thing. If you want authentic food, this is it.
author: Amber R.

description:
I've always passed Chava's while on my way to feed my taco cravings (which usually sound like "tacostacostacostacos!!!"). I finally went in with my dad, and I have to say it was one of the better meals I've had in a long time.

This is not a taqueria, as Rob B. has said. And even though they are a Mexican restaurant, you will not find taqueria type food on their menu. Please don't come to Chava's expecting the best burrito in the world, because you will not find it and you will begin to cry, and no one wants that.

The reason to come to Chava's is their soups. They are simply amazing. All the other dishes are very good too, but there's something about the soups. They give you giant handmade tortillas, which come in handy with all the meals. Also, this is one of the very few (or maybe the only) places that give you salsa AND guacamole with your complimentary chips.

Chava's is cash only, so leave your plastic at home.
author: Alexis C.

description: used to go to the old location when i was little all the time before the fire. my parents say it just hasn't been the same since. but went again for the caldo de rez.  excluding the mariachi band's trumpet player screeching away at the birthday party in the back, the food was still good. huge bowl of hot beef chunks and veggies in steaming broth. finished with unions, lemon, rice and BAM! happiness in a bowl on a cold SF night. i'm such a soup junkie.
author: Katie M.

description:
im glad this place still gets such great reviews. as i am sure the owners try hard and they deserve this positive attention.

i guess i will always miss the old Chavas. it always felt like i was in a divey mexican joint south of the boarder. all the families coming in after church on Saturdays nary a bit of english being spoken and the food was just like mamma makes.

i think the new chavas is great and if you dont have the old to compare dont hesatate to enjoy just know you are missing our on something that can not and may not ever be replicated here in sf. oh nastalga
author: Jorge E.

description: I went here to satisfy a serious chilaquiles craving and was bitterly disappointed.  The chilaquiles were greasy and bland, and my partner's dinner was equally unappetizing.  We won't be going back.
author: Andi T.

description: Most of you young Mission hipster's think that Mexican's only make burritos. Chava's is known for it's soup. AHHHHHHHH! This is the best soup to have after you're hung over. Try the goat soup or the beef soup. AHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHH! I'm going there first thing tommorow. I'm getting hungry again.
author: Glenn C.

description: I used to go to the old location back in the day. But I missed the notice of "the move" so all I had was my memories of the best heuvos rancheros I'd ever had. Then one day the hubby wants to go to Rosamunde and lo and behold across the street is the "promised land" ! I promised to eat sausages that day,(huge disappointment -we won't be going back) but the next week was my turn to pick ~ and Chava's it was! Everything they say about the tortillas, the huge portions,and  the incredible tastes are true. Hubby had the Chicharone with salsa verde, he was in heaven. The service was fast and friendly. The place was clean. What else can I say? Perfection.
author: Lee P.

description:
this place is ok... nothing too special about their dishes really...
but then again i haven't tried their birria yet...
author: charlotte s.

description: Tortillas tortillas tortillas!  Even if their other food wasn't good, you'd go here for the heavenly tortillas.  The good news is the other food is quite good. Delicious huevos scrambles are my favorite for breakfast (screw toast, fresh tortillas rule any day).  The soups are great, the pork dishes are solid, the staff is friendly and the place isn't too busy.  Bring your appetite here whenever you're in the mood for some good Mexican food, especially fresh tortillas.
author: Al K.

description: Yes I gave it four stars....what!?    Most of my friends hate it.  If you've ever grown up in a Latino neighborhood and now live far from it, you'll know Chava's brings nostalgic feelings of home.  Chava's provides that for me when I eat, see, and taste the chilaquiles, chorizo con huevos, chile colorado, greasy beans, fresh corn tortillas, and the super sweet, busy servers that look like my aunts back home.  I prefer coming here for breakfast/brunch. The jukebox is always playing the latest and greatest hits from our ranchos south of the border and, for the most part, my food comes before I can even say what I want to drink.  I think I also gave it four stars because it's a block from home.  I do miss the old Chava's closer to 18th, but was burned down.
author: Adrian N.

description: Great huevos rancheros.  They make their own tortillas fresh and they are sooo good.  Great dessert selection, too.
author: Dong T.

description:
Everything satisfies here. The service is friendly and attentive. Even to gringos like me. 

I've not had a dish here that wasn't huge, delicious, and cheap.  The birria is a rare treat of tender mutton in a spicy broth. The quesadilla appetizer is as big as a meal for two. The chilaquiles are an excellent Mexican breakfast/ brunch food. 

If you like authentic Mexican food and you want to leave with both a full belly AND a full wallet, this is the place to go.
author: Joe S.

description: I had the chiliquiles here for breakfast once and they were awesome. Yummy strips of tortilla fried with beans and eggs. Carbolicious. Definitely woth checking out once in a while. The portions here are huge so if you have a small appetite you might want to share.
author: Cathy T.

description: I liked the home-style feel of this place ... the nachos were spectacular. We didn't stay for lunch bc there were no burritos on the menu!!! I didn't really care too much, but the people I was with really wanted a burrito. I would go back to try the enchiladas on their menu.
author: Antara B.

description: Bowls of soup the size of your head... to cure what ails you. Toss in all the sides that are served with the chicken soup, squeeze in a little fresh lemon juice and you're good to go -- that cold is history!
author: Emily D.

description: Don't come here for a burrito.  You won't find it.  Free chips, salsa fresca, and guacamole prepared me for a fine meal.  They have your basics like enchiladas, tacos, but also a lot of less common dishes by San Francisco standards.  The next time I will try the ceviche tostada, move on to one their soups, and will finish it off with the flan that looks so delicious!
author: T D.

description: My roommate has been talking this place up.  He said it's better than Olivo's in Nob Hill.  So i took the pepsi challenge.  I ordered the exact same combo as i did at Olivo's.  It was a close one.  Chava's gets the edge on chips and salsa, but overall I have to give the nod to Olivo's.  It just seems like Olivo's is a little more homecooked, while Chava's has a more mass appeal taste.  Don't get me wrong Chava's was excellent, but it was just missing that little extra that Olivo's has.
author: Tony S.

description: The service is terrible.  It takes forever to get a glass of water, the food is not what I expected since it closed on 18th Street.   So you get chips and salsa....for a family of 6 they give a tiny one and when you try to order more, they take another 15 minutes to bring them.  The flavor of the food...well its no longer there.  I used to love going there for the birria...had it the other day.  Did not like it.  It was salty and the flavor was just not the same.  The posole which I love...was bland.  The color was too clear and it just wasnt for me.  Not a place I would ever go to for some real good mexican food.  Not at all.  I'd rather eat at home.
author: lori c.

description: Go on the weekends and order their soup.  Basically the Menudo (tripe) and Birria (goat).  So good people come with their own pots so that they can take the soup home.
author: Jumbo J.

description:
You are not in KANSAS anymore and CAMPBELL's can soup won't do...Fantastic Mexican Soup with substance.
Do miss the previous location with it casa shack  hut design. I usually just go for the mexican caldos (soup)..true authentic chicken and beef caldos full of vitamins and protiens....great for the day after partying or long love sessions...volver a la vida...
Bring your spanish dictionaries or else spanglish works just fine.
author: Jake S.

description:
Here's the deal: if you want great, delicious typical mexican dishes, Chavas has it with great service by some rather saucy waitresses who want to be your mother/aunt/sister/wife/girlfriend/best friend/take your pick.

One thing that makes this place FANTASTIC -- on a restricted diet? Believe it or not, some of their dishes are not all that fattening (I'M SERIOUS). Take the poached white fish in a slightly spicy chipotle sauce (pescado a la diabla) or the stewed pollo a la mexicana. Sure, they come with beans, rice, salad and tortillas, but just ask them to substitute more salad for the rice and beans AND be sure to tell them no salad dressing, cream or that (I think awful) mexican style parmesian, and guess what? They will accommodate you!!!! BUT, please don't miss out on their wonderful home made tortillas, and don't leave before waving at the neglected tortilla maker (she loves the attention!!!).
author: John G.

description: Looks like a taqueria but actually a table service restaurant. Good homemade tortillas. Bland beans but good spicy sauces. Best part--half-empty jug of Gallo Burgundy sitting on the shelf. House wine! Oh, and the jukebox is entertaining too.
author: L J.

description: if you are tejano, this place is for you, if you want mex-mex, go somewhere else... that being said, this place had some delicious beans, they were open later than most places, and they had some vicente fernandez on the jukebox... and cheap food... friendly peeps working
author: .V X V.

description: great service, great food , the chicken milanese is really good they have the best rice in the world, on top of that free dessert on the house, try it people dont stay home get out plenty of goo underated places of mission
author: NAEL K.

description: I am sorely disappointed at the A-ok reviews.  My father said he began eating at Chava's back in the 80's.  One of his buddies knew the owner.  Then Chava's closed, and my dad was heartbroken.  When he stumbled upon it again one fine day, he tried it out and said the food was the same as it was back in the day.  He recently brought my brother and me there for lunch.  We all ordered various types of enchilladas.  No one complained.  Their home-made tortillas are so scrumptious!!  Soft and fluffy..mmmm...next time I go there I need to order something that doesn't already come wrapped in a thin corn tortilla, just so I will have more room in my tummy to gobble down more of those fluffy ones!  I found the service to be very quick and friendly.  And don't forget to order an horchata!  So sweet.  So cinnamon-y.  I am looking forward to many more pleasant lunches there with my daddy-o, now that I am all grown up.
author: Kandi K.

description: It was with great trepidation that my friend and I returned to Chava's in its current location. The heartbreak of the fire that destroyed the original location felt like the loss of a good friend and a delightful "locals" tradition. Chava's was a place where Mexican families enjoyed a big Sunday morning breakfast right next to hipsters, gay couples, and the usual melange of working class humanity in The Mission. We felt like fools when our breakfasts arrived, because as it turns out we had very wrongly assumed that the quality would be compromised by the change of venue. The only things lost in the move were the friendly forced intimacy of the communal tables and frankly, some of the dinginess. The new location is much cleaner and brighter, and the food is exactly the same, which is a compliment. I ordered the oversized Caldo de Pollo and my friend had his favorite chilequiles. Both fantastic, served with fresh garnishes and salsas. I had forgotten how delicious Chava's fresh tortillas were. Good enough to munch alone without filling or salsa. We couldn't finish our huge meal, which came in at about twenty dollars for both. "Free," joked my well-fed pal. We thoroughly enjoyed the Norteno duo who sang some Conjunto music for the diners, as well as the very friendly service. Chava's is a casual local gem.
author: Dean E.
